docs.lead_paragraph: SMALL--Trudy N.,MD The Departments of Pediatrics and Laboratory Medicine and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourn the passing of Trudy N. Small, MD, who died on June 14th, 2013. Dr. Small was an internationally recognized pediatric hematologist who made important contributions in the development of improved transplantation approaches for the treatment of patients with advanced leukemia and children with life-threatening genetic disorders of the immune system. Dr. Small received her medical degree from SUNY Upstate Medical University of Syracuse and residency training in Pediatrics at Duke University and the University of Minnesota. After specialty training in Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, she joined the faculty in 1987 and thereafter rose to its highest rank of full Member. She was also an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Small's research focused on the cellular interactions that control recovery of the immune system after transplantation, and provided the first evidence linking age-related changes in the human thymus with the delayed restoration of cell-mediated immunity observed in older adults after transplantation. She also conducted pioneering studies examining how best to vaccinate patients after transplantation or other cancer treatments to insure full recovery of immunity and protect patients from infection. Her work provided evidence critical to the development of the National Centers for Disease Control's guidelines for vaccination of immunocompromised transplant recipients. Dr. Small's research on lethal genetic immune deficiencies also contributed to more precise characteristics that clarified diagnoses and improved transplantation approaches for curative correction. Dr. Small dedicated her professional life to the care of children who received marrow transplants for life-threatening forms of leukemia and immune deficiency. As a physician and parent, she had a profound understanding of the potentially devastating impact of these diseases on children and their families and how challenging the journey back to health can be. She also had a special way with children that turned fears to confidence and laughter. Dr. Small was beloved by her patients and their families and warmly revered by her many friends and colleagues. She is survived by her husband, Robert Knowles, and her children, Molly and Sam. She will be deeply missed. Richard J. O'Reilly, MD Chair, Department of Pediatrics Melissa S. Pessin, MD, PhD Chair, Department of Laboratory Medicine Jose Baselga, MD, PhD Physician-in-Chief, Memorial Hospital

docs.lead_paragraph: An international team found that a person can get sick 5.2 days after being exposed to the MERS virus, which has infected 64 people in 38 countries.

headline.main: Investigation Follows Trail of a Virus in Hospitals
headline.print_headline: Investigation Follows Trail Of a Virus In Hospitals

docs.abstract: Detailed investigation of MERS viral illness, first detected in Saudi Arabia in 2012, reveals chilling ease with which virus can spread to ill patients in hospital; international team found that a person can get sick 5.2 days after being exposed to virus, which has infected 64 people in 38 countries; report is published in New England Journal of Medicine.
docs.snippet: An international team found that a person can get sick 5.2 days after being exposed to the MERS virus, which has infected 64 people in 38 countries.

headline.main: Using Data to Stage-Manage Paths to the Prescription Counter
headline.print_headline: Stage-Managing Paths to the Prescription Counter

docs.abstract: CVS and other retailers are using customer data to tailor the shopping experience and encourage repeat visits.
docs.snippet: CVS and other retailers are using customer data to tailor the shopping experience and encourage repeat visits.

headline.main: In New Tools to Combat Epidemics, the Key Is Context
headline.print_headline: In New Tools to Combat Epidemics, the Key Is Context

docs.abstract: BioMosaic, which tracks foreign-borne disease threats in the United States, works by merging three separate data tools into a single app for guiding decisions at the time of an outbreak.
docs.snippet: BioMosaic, which tracks foreign-borne disease threats in the United States, works by merging three separate data tools into a single app for guiding decisions at the time of an outbreak.

headline.print_headline: Harming Our Health With Eyes Wide Open

docs.abstract: Failing to get enough sleep night after night can compromise your health and may even shorten your life.
docs.snippet: Failing to get enough sleep night after night can compromise your health and may even shorten your life.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wild chimpanzees have been listed as endangered since 1990, but a new proposal covers all chimps, including nearly 2,000 captive in the United States today.

headline.print_headline: Goal of Broader Protection for Chimpanzees Emerges From Changing Perspectives

docs.abstract: New Fish and Wildlife Service proposal will classify all chimpanzees as endangered, including nearly 2,000 captive chimpanzees in the United States; if enacted, rule will be major success for animal welfare groups, grave disappointment for some scientists and another sign of profound changes in the way animals are used and imagined in science and popular culture.
docs.snippet: Wild chimpanzees have been listed as endangered since 1990, but a new proposal covers all chimps, including nearly 2,000 captive in the United States today.
